--- title: "Probability" categories: - primer - probability date: 05/23/2023 --- # Basics of Probability **Probability** is a numerical measure of the likelihood of that event's occurrence. It takes on a value in the interval $[0, 1]$. A **sample space** is a collection of all possible outcomes in a random process. The sum of all probabilities in the sample space must sum to 1. An **event** is a collection of one or more outcomes from a process whose result cannot be predicted. The probability of event $X$ is expressed as $P(X)$ ## Basic Relationships ### Complement Event consisting of all sample points that are not in $A$. $$ P(\bar{A}) = 1 - P(A) $$ ### Union The union of an event $A$ and event $B$ is the event containing all sample points in $A$ or $B$ or both. $$ A \cup B $$ ### Intersection All sample points that are in **both** $A$ and $B$. $$ A \cap B $$ ### Addition Law $$ P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $$ ### Mutually Exclusive Mutually exclusive meants that events have no sample points in common--they do not intersect. The events cannot both occur which turns the addition law into $$ P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) $$ ### Conditional Properties Probability of an event given that another event has occurred. $$ P(A | B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} $$ ### Multiplication Law We derive this from the conditional property which expresses the intersection as a multiplication: $$ \begin{align*} P(A \cap B) &= P(A | B) \cdot P(B) \\ &= P(B | A) \cdot P(A) \end{align*} $$ If events are independent then this becomes $$ P(A \cap B) = P(A) \cdot P(B) $$ # Independent and Dependent Events An **independent event** means that the occurrence of one event doesn't influence the probability of the other. $$ \begin{align*} P(A | B) &= P(A) \\ P(B | A) &= P(B) \end{align*} $$ - Event B has no bearing on the occurence of event A and vice versa ## Conditional vs. Marginal Probabilities **Marginal probabilities** are considered unconditional probabilities--they are probabilities of events without any condition. ### Example > Let's take a look at promotion of people at a company with advanced degrees vs. those who don't have them. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd d = {'yes': {'promoted': 288, 'not_promoted': 672}, 'no': {'promoted': 36, 'not_promoted': 204}} df = pd.DataFrame(d) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html}
yes no
promoted 288 36
not_promoted 672 204
``` ::: ::: One marginal probability is the probability of an advanced degree: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} prob_adv_deg = df['yes'].sum() / (df['yes'].sum() + df['no'].sum()) prob_adv_deg ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ``` 0.8 ``` ::: ::: On the other hand, a conditional probability might be the probability of a promotion given that the employee has no advanced degree: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} cond_prob = df.loc['promoted', 'no'] / df['no'].sum() cond_prob ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` 0.15 ``` ::: ::: # Distributions
